unnormalised: It was a typically chaotic scene at Indira Gandhi International Airport in Delhi. The usual rush of passengers, the incessant announcements, the aroma of filter coffee from the South Indian cafe – all contributing to the sensory overload one expects before a long journey. I was there, not for leisure, but on assignment. Air Deccan, or rather what was left of it, was making its last flight ever.

unnormalised: Capt. Ravi Sharma, a veteran pilot with 25 yrs of flying experience, was at the helm of this final voyage. I spotted him near gate 42, chatting with the ground staff. He looked weary, but there was a certain resolve in his eyes. Air Deccan, once a pioneer of low-cost air travel in India, had been struggling for yrs. Its founder, Capt. Gopinath, a visionary if ever there was one, had democratized flying for the masses. But changing economic landscapes and fierce competition had taken their toll.

unnormalised: As I disembarked, I saw Capt. Ravi Sharma standing near the cockpit door, bidding farewell to each passenger. There was a hint of a smile on his face, but I could sense the weight of the occasion. He had piloted Air Deccan through turbulent times, and now he was seeing it off into history. The aircraft, DN101, parked at gate no. 5, would never fly again under the Air Deccan banner. But the memories, the stories, and the legacy of the airline would continue to soar, forever etched in the annals of Indian aviation. Perhaps, in the near future, it could be revived under a new name, “Deccan 2.0”. Only time will tell.
